Zero-Shot Prediction To provide a qualitative summary / overview of CLIP's zeroshot performance we visualize a randomly selected prediction for 36 different zero-shot CLIP classifiers in Figure [21.](#page-41-0) In addition, Table [11](#page-42-0) and Figure [22](#page-42-0) show the individual zero-shot performance scores for each dataset. # C. Duplicate Detector

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_339
chunks.content:
# C. Duplicate Detector

Our early attempts at duplicate detection and analysis used nearest neighbors in the model's learned embedding space. While it is intuitive to use a model's own notion of similarity, we encountered issues. We found the model's feature space is weighted very heavily towards semantic similarity. Many false positives occurred due to distinct objects that would be described similarly (soccer balls, flowers of the same species, etc...) having almost perfect similarity. We also observed the model was quite poor at assigning certain kinds of near-duplicates high similarity scores. We noticed repeatedly that images with high-frequency textures (such as fur or stripe patterns) pre-processed by different resizing algorithms (nearest neighbor vs bi-linear) could have surprisingly low similarity. This resulted in many false negatives.

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_340
chunks.content: We built our own near-duplicate detector to fix this issue. We created a synthetic data augmentation pipeline that combined a variety of common image manipulations. The augmentation pipeline combines random cropping and zooming, aspect ratio distortion, downsizing and upscaling to different resolutions, minor rotations, jpeg compression, and HSV color jitter. The pipeline also randomly selects from different interpolation algorithms for all relevant steps. We then trained a model to maximize the similarity of an image and its transformed variant while minimizing similarity to all other images in a training batch. We used the same n-pair / InfoNCE loss as CLIP but with a fixed temperature of 0.07.

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_341
chunks.content: We selected a ResNet-50 as the model architecture. We modified the base ResNet-50 with the anti-alias improvements from [\(Zhang,](#page-35-0) [2019\)](#page-35-0) and used weight norm [\(Sali](#page-33-0)[mans & Kingma,](#page-33-0) [2016\)](#page-33-0) instead of batch norm [\(Ioffe &](#page-29-0) [Szegedy,](#page-29-0) [2015\)](#page-29-0) to avoid leaking information about duplicates via batch statistics - a problem previously noted in [\(Henaff,](#page-29-0) [2020\)](#page-29-0). We also found the GELU activation function [\(Hendrycks & Gimpel,](#page-29-0) [2016\)](#page-29-0) to perform better for this task. We trained the model with a total batch size of 1,712 for approximately 30 million images sampled from our pretraining dataset. At the end of training it achieves nearly 100% accuracy on its proxy training task.

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_342
Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_343
Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_344
chunks.content:
Table 12. CLIP performs similarly when trained on only YFCC100M. Comparing a ResNet-50 trained on only YFCC100M with a same sized subset of WIT shows similar average performance and number of wins on zero shot and linear classifier evals. However, large differences in dataset specific performance occur. We include performance on the 3 datasets where YFCC does best and worst compared to WIT according to a linear probe in order to highlight this as well as aggregate performance across all linear and zero-shot evals and the canonical ImageNet dataset.

# D. Dataset Ablation on YFCC100M

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_345
chunks.content: To study whether our custom dataset is critical to the performance of CLIP, we trained a model on a filtered subset of the YFCC100M dataset (details described in Section [2.2\)](#page-2-0) and compared its performance to the same model trained on an equally sized subset of WIT. We train each model for 32 epochs at which point transfer performance begins to plateau due to overfitting. Results are shown in Table 12. Across our whole eval suite, YFCC and WIT perform similarly on average for both zero-shot and linear probe settings. However, performance on specific fine-grained classification datasets can vary widely - sometimes by over 10%. Our speculation is that these differences in performance reflect the relative density of relevant data in each pre-training dataset

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_346
chunks.content: . Our speculation is that these differences in performance reflect the relative density of relevant data in each pre-training dataset. For instance, pre-training on YFCC100M, which might contain many photos of birds and flowers (common subjects for photographers), results in better performance on Birdsnap and Flowers102, while pre-training on WIT results in better car and pet classifiers (which appear common in our dataset).

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_347
chunks.content: Overall, these results are encouraging as they suggest our approach can use any reasonably filtered collection of paired (text, image) data. This mirrors recent work which reported positive results using the same contrastive pre-training objective on the relatively different domain of medical imaging [\(Zhang et al.,](#page-35-0) [2020\)](#page-35-0). It also is similar to the findings of noisy student self-training which reported only slight improvements when using their JFT300M dataset over YFCC100M [\(Xie et al.,](#page-34-0) [2020\)](#page-34-0). We suspect the major advantage of our dataset over the already existing YFCC100M is its much larger size.

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_348
chunks.content: Finally, we caution that WIT includes this filtered subset of YFCC100M. This could result in our ablation underestimating the size of performance differences between YFCC100M and the rest of WIT. We do not think this is likely as YFCC100M is only 3.7% of the overall WIT data blend and it did not noticeably change the performance of models when it was added to the existing data blend during the creation of WIT. # E. Selected Task and Dataset Results Due to the large variety of datasets and experiments considered in this work, the main body focuses on summarizing and analyzing overall results. In the following subsections we report details of performance for specific groups of tasks, datasets, and evaluation settings.

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_349
chunks.content: ### E.1. Image and Text Retrieval

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_350
chunks.content: CLIP pre-trains for the task of image-text retrieval on our noisy web-scale dataset. Although the focus of this paper is on representation learning and task learning for the purpose of transfer to a wide variety of downstream datasets, validating that CLIP is able to achieve high transfer performance transfer on exactly what it is pre-trained for is an important sanity check / proof of concept. In Table [13](#page-45-0) we check the zero-shot transfer performance of CLIP for both text and image retrieval on the Flickr30k and MSCOCO datsets. Zero-shot CLIP matches or outperforms all prior zero-shot results on these two datasets. Zero-shot CLIP is also competitive with the current overall SOTA for the task of text retrieval on Flickr30k. On image retrieval, CLIP's performance relative to the overall state of the art is noticeably lower. However, zero-shot CLIP is still competitive with a fine-tuned Unicoder-VL

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_351
chunks.content: . On image retrieval, CLIP's performance relative to the overall state of the art is noticeably lower. However, zero-shot CLIP is still competitive with a fine-tuned Unicoder-VL. On the larger MS-COCO dataset fine-tuning improves performance significantly and zero-shot CLIP is not competitive with the most recent work. For both these datasets we prepend the prompt "a photo of" to the description of each image which we found boosts CLIP's zero-shot R@1 performance between 1 and 2 points.

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_352
chunks.content:
#### E.2. Optical Character Recognition

Although visualizations have shown that ImageNet models contain features that respond to the presence of text in an image [\(Zeiler & Fergus,](#page-35-0) [2014\)](#page-35-0), these representations are not sufficiently fine-grained to use for the task of optical character recognition (OCR). To compensate, models are augmented with the outputs of custom OCR engines and features to boost performance on tasks where this capability is required [\(Singh et al.,](#page-33-0) [2019;](#page-33-0) [Yang et al.,](#page-34-0) [2020\)](#page-34-0). Early during the development of CLIP, we noticed that CLIP began to learn primitive OCR capabilities which appeared to steadily improve over the course of the project. To evaluate this qualitatively noticed behavior, we measured performance

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_353
chunks.content: on 5 datasets requiring the direct and indirect use of OCR. Three of these datasets MNIST [\(LeCun\)](#page-30-0), SVHN [\(Netzer](#page-32-0) [et al.,](#page-32-0) [2011\)](#page-32-0), and IIIT5K [\(Mishra et al.,](#page-31-0) [2012\)](#page-31-0) directly check the ability of a model to perform low-level character and word recognition, while Hateful Memes [\(Kiela et al.,](#page-30-0) [2020\)](#page-30-0) and SST-2 [\(Socher et al.,](#page-33-0) [2013\)](#page-33-0) check the ability of a model to use OCR to perform a semantic task. Results are reported in Table [14.](#page-45-0)

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_354
chunks.content: CLIP's performance is still highly variable and appears to be sensitive to some combination of the domain (rendered or natural images) and the type of text to be recognized (numbers or words). CLIP's OCR performance is strongest Hateful Memes and SST-2 - datasets where the text is digitally rendered and consists mostly of words. On IIIT5K, which is natural images of individually cropped words, zero-shot CLIP performs a bit more respectively and its performance is similar to [Jaderberg et al.](#page-29-0) [\(2014\)](#page-29-0) early work combining deep learning and structured prediction to perform openvocabulary OCR. However, performance is noticeably lower on two datasets involving recognition of hand written and street view numbers. CLIP's 51% accuracy on full number SVHN is well below any published results. Inspection suggests CLIP struggles with repeated characters as well as the low resolution and blurry images of SVHN

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_355
chunks.content: . CLIP's 51% accuracy on full number SVHN is well below any published results. Inspection suggests CLIP struggles with repeated characters as well as the low resolution and blurry images of SVHN. CLIP's zeroshot MNIST performance is also poor and is outperformed by supervised logistic regression on raw pixels, one of the simplest possible machine learning baselines.

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_356
chunks.content: SST-2 is a sentence level NLP dataset which we render into images. We include SST-2 in order to check whether CLIP is able to convert low level OCR capability into a higher level representation. Fitting a linear classifier on CLIP's representation of rendered sentences achives 80.5% accuracy. This is on par with the 80% accuracy of a continuous bag of words baseline using GloVe word vectors pre-trained on 840 billion tokens [\(Pennington et al.,](#page-32-0) [2014\)](#page-32-0). While this is a simple NLP baseline by today's standard, and well below the 97.5% of the current SOTA, it is encouraging to see that CLIP is able to turn an image of rendered text into a non-trivial sentence level representation. Fully supervised CLIP is also surprisingly strong on Hateful Meme detection, where CLIP is only 0.7 points behind the current single model SOTA and several points above the best baseline from the original paper

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_357
chunks.content: . Similar to SST-2, these other results on Hateful Memes use the ground truth text which CLIP does not have access to. Finally, we note that zero-shot CLIP outperforms the best results using fully supervised linear probes across all other 56 models included in our evaluation suite. This suggests CLIP's OCR capability is at least somewhat unique compared to existing work on self-supervised and supervised representation learning.

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_367
chunks.content:
#### E.3. Action Recognition in Videos

For the purpose of learning, a potentially important aspect of natural language is its ability to express, and therefore supervise, an extremely wide set of concepts. A CLIP model, since it is trained to pair semi-arbitrary text with images, is likely to receive supervision for a wide range of visual concepts involving both common and proper nouns, verbs, and adjectives. ImageNet-1K, by contrast, only labels common nouns. Does the lack of broader supervision in ImageNet result in weaker transfer of ImageNet models to tasks involving the recognition of visual concepts that are not nouns?

To investigate this, we measure and compare the performance of CLIP and ImageNet models on several video

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_368
Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_369
chunks.content: Table 15. Action recognition performance on 3 video datasets. Single model SOTA reported to best of knowledge. Note that *linear CLIP* and *linear NS ENet-L2* are trained and evaluated on a single frame subsampled version of each dataset and not directly comparable to prior work. On Kinetics-700, we report the ActivityNet competition metric which is the average of top-1 and top-5 performance.  ${}^a(\text{Kalfaoglu et al., }2020)$   ${}^b(\text{Lu et al., }2020)$   ${}^c(\text{Xie et al., }2020)$   ${}^d(\text{Miech et al., }2020b)$   ${}^e(\text{Carreira et al., }2019)$   ${}^f(\text{Alayrac et al., }2020)$

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_370
chunks.content: action classification datasets which measure the ability of a model to recognize verbs. In Table 15 we report results on UCF-101 (Soomro et al., 2012) and Kinetics-700 (Carreira et al., 2019), two common datasets for the task. Unfortunately, our CPU based linear classifier takes a prohibitively long time to evaluate on a video dataset due to the very large number of training frames. To deal with this, we aggressively sub-sample each video to only a single center frame, effectively turning it into an image classification dataset. As a result, our reported performance in a linear evaluation setting likely under estimates performance by a moderate amount.

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_371
Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_372
chunks.content: Table 16. Detailed ImageNet robustness performance. IN is used to abbreviate for ImageNet. <sup>a</sup> [\(Xie et al.,](#page-34-0) [2020\)](#page-34-0) b [\(Touvron et al.,](#page-34-0) [2019\)](#page-34-0)

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_373
chunks.content: Despite this handicap, CLIP features transfer surprisingly well to this task. CLIP matches the best prior result on UCF-101 in a linear probe evaluation setting and also outperforms all other models in our evaluation suite. On Kinetics-700, CLIP also outperforms the fine-tuned I3D baseline from the original paper. Since it does not require a training stage, we report CLIP's zero-shot performance when averaging predictions across all frames. CLIP also performs well in this setting and on Kinetics-700 its performance is within 1% of the fully supervised I3D baseline which is trained on 545000 labeled videos. Encouraged by these results, we also measure CLIP's performance on the recently introduced RareAct dataset [\(Miech et al.,](#page-31-0) [2020a\)](#page-31-0) which was designed to measure zero-shot recognition of unusual actions like "hammering a phone" and "drilling an egg"

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_374
chunks.content: . CLIP improves over the prior state of the art, a S3D model trained on automatically extracted captions from 100 million instructional videos, by 10 points.

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_375
chunks.content:
While CLIP has encouragingly strong performance on the task of action recognition, we note that there are many differences between the models being compared beyond just their form of supervision such as model architecture, training data distribution, dataset size, and compute used. Further work is needed to more precisely determine what specific design decisions contribute to achieving high performance on this task.

Models are ordered by average performance. <sup>a</sup> [\(Muller-Budack et al.,](#page-32-0) [2018\)](#page-32-0) b [\(Hongsuck Seo et al.,](#page-29-0) [2018\)](#page-29-0) c [\(Vo et al.,](#page-34-0) [2017\)](#page-34-0) c [\(Weyand et al.,](#page-34-0) [2016\)](#page-34-0)

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_377
chunks.content:
### E.4. Geolocalization

Another behavior we noticed during the development of CLIP was its ability to recognize many places and locations. To quantify this we created the Country211 dataset as described in Appendix [A](#page-36-0) and report results on it throughout the paper. However it is a new benchmark so to compare with prior work on geolocalization we also report results on the IM2GPS test set from [Hays & Efros](#page-29-0) [\(2008\)](#page-29-0) in Table 17. Since IM2GPS is a regression benchmark, we guess the GPS coordinates of the nearest image in a set of reference images using CLIP's embedding space. This is not a zeroshot result since it uses nearest-neighbor regression. Despite querying only 1 million images, which is much less than prior work, CLIP performs similarly to several task specific models. It is not, however, competitive with the current state of the art.

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_chunk_378
chunks.content:
### E.5. Robustness to Distribution Shift

Section [3.3](#page-12-0) provides a high level summary and analysis of ImageNet-related robustness results. We briefly provide some additional numerical details in this appendix. Performance results per dataset are provided in Table 16 and compared with the current state of the art results reported in [Taori et al.](#page-33-0) [\(2020\)](#page-33-0)'s evaluation suite. Zero-shot CLIP improves the state of the art on 5 of the 7 datasets, ImageNet-R, ObjectNet, ImageNet-Sketch, ImageNet-Vid, and Youtube-BB. CLIP's improvements are largest on ImageNet-Vid and Youtube-BB due to its flexible zero-shot capability and on ImageNet-R, which likely reflects CLIP's pre-training distribution including significant amounts of creative content. A similar behavior has been documented for the Instagram pre-trained ResNeXt models as discussed in [Taori et al.](#page-33-0) [\(2020\)](#page-33-0).

chunks.content:
Figure: Summary of our approach. While standard image models jointly train an image feature extractor and a linear classifier to predict some label, CLIP jointly trains an image encoder and a text encoder to predict the correct pairings of a batch of (image, text) training examples. At test time the learned text encoder synthesizes a zero-shot linear classifier by embedding the names or descriptions of the target dataset's classes.

Visual Description: The figure illustrates the methodology for training a CLIP model using a multi-modal approach that combines image and text encoding. The left side depicts the contrastive pre-training phase, where a text encoder processes textual descriptions (T1, T2, ..., TN) paired with corresponding images (I1, I2, ..., IN), generating a matrix of embeddings that facilitate the model’s learning of aligned representations. On the right, the figure demonstrates how a dataset classifier is created from label text, leading to zero-shot predictions during inference, where the learned representations are employed to classify unseen images based on descriptions such as "A photo of a dog." Key findings emphasize the model's ability to perform zero-shot classification using synthetic classifiers conditioned on text input, showcasing enhanced flexibility

metadata.caption: Summary of our approach. While standard image models jointly train an image feature extractor and a linear classifier to predict some label, CLIP jointly trains an image encoder and a text encoder to predict the correct pairings of a batch of (image, text) training examples. At test time the learned text encoder synthesizes a zero-shot linear classifier by embedding the names or descriptions of the target dataset's classes.

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_figure_2
chunks.content: Figure: CLIP is much more efficient at zero-shot transfer than our image caption baseline. Although highly expressive, we found that transformer-based language models are relatively weak at zero-shot ImageNet classification. Here, we see that it learns 3x slower than a baseline which predicts a bag-of-words (BoW) encoding of the text (Joulin et al., 2016). Swapping the prediction objective for the contrastive objective of CLIP further improves efficiency another 4x. Visual Description: The figure illustrates the zero-shot ImageNet classification accuracy against the number of images processed, with three different approaches represented: Bag of Words Contrastive (CLIP), Bag of Words Prediction, and Transformer Language Model. The x-axis denotes the number of images processed (ranging from 2M to 400M), while the y-axis displays the accuracy in percentage. Key findings indicate that CLIP (green line) achieves a notable efficiency, reaching a zero-shot accuracy of 25% after processing 268 million images, outperforming the Bag of Words Prediction (orange line) by 3x and the Transformer Language Model (blue line) by a substantial margin, which exhibits slower growth in accuracy. Swapping to a contrastive objective offers an additional

metadata.caption: CLIP is much more efficient at zero-shot transfer than our image caption baseline. Although highly expressive, we found that transformer-based language models are relatively weak at zero-shot ImageNet classification. Here, we see that it learns 3x slower than a baseline which predicts a bag-of-words (BoW) encoding of the text (Joulin et al., 2016). Swapping the prediction objective for the contrastive objective of CLIP further improves efficiency another 4x.

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_figure_3
chunks.content:
Figure: Prompt engineering and ensembling improve zeroshot performance. Compared to the baseline of using contextless class names, prompt engineering and ensembling boost zero-shot classification performance by almost 5 points on average across 36 datasets. This improvement is similar to the gain from using 4 times more compute with the baseline zero-shot method but is "free" when amortized over many predictions.

Visual Description: The figure illustrates the average performance scores of various models in relation to their computational efficiency (measured in GFLOPs). The x-axis represents the model's GFLOPs, while the y-axis indicates the average score as a percentage. Key findings show that the implementation of prompt engineering and ensembling (represented by green markers) consistently outperforms the baseline method utilizing contextless class names (blue markers), achieving nearly a 5% increase in performance on average across 36 datasets, which is comparable to the gains realized from using four times more computational resources with the baseline method.

metadata.caption: Prompt engineering and ensembling improve zeroshot performance. Compared to the baseline of using contextless class names, prompt engineering and ensembling boost zero-shot classification performance by almost 5 points on average across 36 datasets. This improvement is similar to the gain from using 4 times more compute with the baseline zero-shot method but is "free" when amortized over many predictions.

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_figure_4
chunks.content:
Figure: Zero-shot CLIP is competitive with a fully supervised baseline. Across a 27 dataset eval suite, a zero-shot CLIP classifier outperforms a fully supervised linear classifier fitted on ResNet-50 features on 16 datasets, including ImageNet.

Visual Description: The figure illustrates the performance comparison between a zero-shot CLIP classifier and a fully supervised linear classifier fitted on ResNet-50 features across 27 datasets, with the x-axis labeled as "Δ Score (%)" indicating the difference in scores. The data trends show that the zero-shot CLIP outperforms the supervised baseline on 16 datasets, as indicated by the green bars, with notable successes on StanfordCars (+28.9) and Country211 (+23.2). In contrast, the zero-shot method performs poorly on several datasets, represented by the blue bars, with EuroSAT showing the lowest score at -37.1.

metadata.caption: Zero-shot CLIP is competitive with a fully supervised baseline. Across a 27 dataset eval suite, a zero-shot CLIP classifier outperforms a fully supervised linear classifier fitted on ResNet-50 features on 16 datasets, including ImageNet.

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_figure_5
chunks.content:
Figure: Zero-shot CLIP outperforms few-shot linear probes. Zero-shot CLIP matches the average performance of a 4-shot linear classifier trained on the same feature space and nearly matches the best results of a 16-shot linear classifier across publicly available models. For both BiT-M and SimCLRv2, the best performing model is highlighted. Light gray lines are other models in the eval suite. The 20 datasets with at least 16 examples per class were used in this analysis.

Visual Description: The figure presents a comparison of various models' performance based on the number of labeled training examples per class, with the y-axis labeled "Average Score (%)" and the x-axis labeled "# of labeled training examples per class." Key findings indicate that Zero-shot CLIP outperforms the few-shot linear probes and achieves a performance level comparable to a 4-shot linear classifier, while nearing the best results of a 16-shot linear classifier. The best-performing models, BiT-M and SimCLRv2, are highlighted, and the light gray lines represent other models within the evaluation suite.

metadata.caption: Zero-shot CLIP outperforms few-shot linear probes. Zero-shot CLIP matches the average performance of a 4-shot linear classifier trained on the same feature space and nearly matches the best results of a 16-shot linear classifier across publicly available models. For both BiT-M and SimCLRv2, the best performing model is highlighted. Light gray lines are other models in the eval suite. The 20 datasets with at least 16 examples per class were used in this analysis.

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_figure_6
chunks.content: Figure: The data efficiency of zero-shot transfer varies widely. Calculating the number of labeled examples per class a linear classifier on the same CLIP feature space requires to match the performance of the zero-shot classifier contextualizes the effectiveness of zero-shot transfer. Values are estimated based on log-linear interpolation of 1, 2, 4, 8, 16-shot and fully supervised results. Performance varies widely from still underperforming a one-shot classifier on two datasets to matching an estimated 184 labeled examples per class. Visual Description: The academic figure presents a horizontal bar chart illustrating the number of labeled examples per class required to match the performance of a zero-shot classifier across various datasets. The x-axis represents the number of labeled examples needed (ranging from 0 to 200), while the y-axis lists different datasets, with the values reflecting the varying data efficiency of zero-shot transfer. Key findings indicate that while some datasets like FER2013 require as many as 184 labeled examples, others, such as Flowers102, only need 0.9 labeled examples, demonstrating a wide disparity in data efficiency for zero-shot learning. The mean number of labeled examples is 20.8, with a median of 5.4.

metadata.caption: The data efficiency of zero-shot transfer varies widely. Calculating the number of labeled examples per class a linear classifier on the same CLIP feature space requires to match the performance of the zero-shot classifier contextualizes the effectiveness of zero-shot transfer. Values are estimated based on log-linear interpolation of 1, 2, 4, 8, 16-shot and fully supervised results. Performance varies widely from still underperforming a one-shot classifier on two datasets to matching an estimated 184 labeled examples per class.

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_figure_7
chunks.content:
Figure: Zero-shot performance is correlated with linear probe performance but still mostly sub-optimal. Comparing zero-shot and linear probe performance across datasets shows a strong correlation with zero-shot performance mostly shifted 10 to 25 points lower. On only 5 datasets does zero-shot performance approach linear probe performance ( $\leq$ 3 point difference).

Visual Description: The figure presents a scatter plot comparing zero-shot CLIP performance against linear probe CLIP performance across multiple datasets. The x-axis represents linear probe performance, while the y-axis represents zero-shot performance, showing a strong correlation (r = 0.82). Most datasets exhibit a consistent shift in zero-shot performance, falling 10 to 25 points lower than linear probe performance, with only five datasets demonstrating a close alignment (within a 3-point difference).

metadata.caption: Zero-shot performance is correlated with linear probe performance but still mostly sub-optimal. Comparing zero-shot and linear probe performance across datasets shows a strong correlation with zero-shot performance mostly shifted 10 to 25 points lower. On only 5 datasets does zero-shot performance approach linear probe performance ( $\leq$ 3 point difference).

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_figure_8
chunks.content: Figure: Zero-shot CLIP performance scales smoothly as a function of model compute. Across 39 evals on 36 different datasets, average zero-shot error is well modeled by a log-log linear trend across a 44x range of compute spanning 5 different CLIP models. Lightly shaded lines are performance on individual evals, showing that performance is much more varied despite the smooth overall trend. Visual Description: The figure illustrates the relationship between model compute, measured in GFLOPs (x-axis), and zero-shot error percentage (y-axis) for various CLIP models. The data shows a log-log linear trend indicating that increased compute correlates with reduced error, with average zero-shot error decreasing smoothly from approximately 45% to below 35% across the models. Despite the overall trend, individual evaluations exhibit more variability, as indicated by the lightly shaded lines representing performance on specific tasks.

metadata.caption: Zero-shot CLIP performance scales smoothly as a function of model compute. Across 39 evals on 36 different datasets, average zero-shot error is well modeled by a log-log linear trend across a 44x range of compute spanning 5 different CLIP models. Lightly shaded lines are performance on individual evals, showing that performance is much more varied despite the smooth overall trend.

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_figure_9
chunks.content: Figure: Linear probe performance of CLIP models in comparison with state-of-the-art computer vision models, including EfficientNet (Tan & Le, 2019; Xie et al., 2020), MoCo (Chen et al., 2020d), Instagram-pretrained ResNeXt models (Mahajan et al., 2018; Touvron et al., 2019), BiT (Kolesnikov et al., 2019), ViT (Dosovitskiy et al., 2020), SimCLRv2 (Chen et al., 2020c), BYOL (Grill et al., 2020), and the original ResNet models (He et al., 2016b). (Left) Scores are averaged over 12 datasets studied by Kornblith et al. (2019). (Right) Scores are averaged over 27 datasets that contain a wider variety of distributions. Dotted lines indicate models fine-tuned or evaluated on images at a higher-resolution than pre-training. See Table 10 for individual scores and Figure 20 for plots for each dataset. Visual Description: The figure compares the linear probe performance of CLIP models with several state-of-the-art computer vision models, illustrated across two axes: "Forward-pass GFLOPs/image" (x-axis) and "Average Score (%)" (y-axis). The left panel shows average scores over 12 datasets, revealing a consistent trend where CLIP models (notably CLIP-ViT and CLIP-ResNet) achieve higher scores than many traditional architectures, particularly at higher computational costs. The right panel extends the analysis to 27 datasets, indicating that CLIP models continue to outperform most other models, with lines showing a generally increasing trend in performance with greater GFLOPs, particularly for those models fine-tuned at higher resolutions (as indicated by dashed lines

metadata.caption: Linear probe performance of CLIP models in comparison with state-of-the-art computer vision models, including EfficientNet (Tan & Le, 2019; Xie et al., 2020), MoCo (Chen et al., 2020d), Instagram-pretrained ResNeXt models (Mahajan et al., 2018; Touvron et al., 2019), BiT (Kolesnikov et al., 2019), ViT (Dosovitskiy et al., 2020), SimCLRv2 (Chen et al., 2020c), BYOL (Grill et al., 2020), and the original ResNet models (He et al., 2016b). (Left) Scores are averaged over 12 datasets studied by Kornblith et al. (2019). (Right) Scores are averaged over 27 datasets that contain a wider variety of distributions. Dotted lines indicate models fine-tuned or evaluated on images at a higher-resolution than pre-training. See Table 10 for individual scores and Figure 20 for plots for each dataset.

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_figure_10
chunks.content: Figure: CLIP's features outperform the features of the best ImageNet model on a wide variety of datasets. Fitting a linear classifier on CLIP's features outperforms using the Noisy Student EfficientNet-L2 on 21 out of 27 datasets. Visual Description: The figure compares the performance of Logistic Regression classifiers trained on CLIP's features to those trained on the Noisy Student EfficientNet-L2 across various datasets. The x-axis represents the change in score percentage (Δ Score %), while the y-axis lists the datasets. A notable trend is that all but six datasets show positive Δ Score values for CLIP, indicating superior performance, with SST2 and Country211 achieving the highest improvements at +23.6% and +22.7%, respectively. In contrast, several datasets like ImageNet and CIFAR100 show negative scores, highlighting CLIP's effectiveness in generalizing across diverse data categories.

metadata.caption: CLIP's features outperform the features of the best ImageNet model on a wide variety of datasets. Fitting a linear classifier on CLIP's features outperforms using the Noisy Student EfficientNet-L2 on 21 out of 27 datasets.

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_figure_11
chunks.content:
Figure: CLIP's features are more robust to task shift when compared to models pre-trained on ImageNet. For both dataset splits, the transfer scores of linear probes trained on the representations of CLIP models are higher than other models with similar ImageNet performance. This suggests that the representations of models trained on ImageNet are somewhat overfit to their task.

Visual Description: The figures display the linear probe average transfer scores against the ImageNet scores for various models across two dataset splits. Both graphs indicate that CLIP-based models (marked with red stars) consistently achieve higher transfer scores compared to other models, particularly those pre-trained on ImageNet, suggesting that ImageNet-trained models may be overfitting to their specific tasks. The data trends show that as ImageNet performance increases, transfer scores also tend to improve, but models like CLIP demonstrate a superior ability to generalize across datasets.

metadata.caption: CLIP's features are more robust to task shift when compared to models pre-trained on ImageNet. For both dataset splits, the transfer scores of linear probes trained on the representations of CLIP models are higher than other models with similar ImageNet performance. This suggests that the representations of models trained on ImageNet are somewhat overfit to their task.

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_figure_12
chunks.content: Figure: Zero-shot CLIP is much more robust to distribution shift than standard ImageNet models. (Left) An ideal robust model (dashed line) performs equally well on the ImageNet distribution and on other natural image distributions. Zero-shot CLIP models shrink this "robustness gap" by up to 75%. Linear fits on logit transformed values are shown with bootstrap estimated 95% confidence intervals. (Right) Visualizing distribution shift for bananas, a class shared across 5 of the 7 natural distribution shift datasets. The performance of the best zero-shot CLIP model, ViT-L/14@336px, is compared with a model that has the same performance on the ImageNet validation set, ResNet-101. Visual Description: The figure presents a comparison of model performance on natural image distribution shifts. The left panel's graph plots the average performance on seven datasets (y-axis) against the average performance on a subsampled ImageNet (x-axis), with axes labeled accordingly. Key trends indicate that zero-shot CLIP models (blue circles) considerably outperform standard ImageNet training models (dark blue) and existing robustness techniques (gray), closing the robustness gap by up to 75%. The right panel showcases sample images from various datasets, demonstrating zero-shot CLIP's enhanced performance, particularly highlighted by increases in accuracy for specific datasets compared to ResNet-101.

metadata.caption: Zero-shot CLIP is much more robust to distribution shift than standard ImageNet models. (Left) An ideal robust model (dashed line) performs equally well on the ImageNet distribution and on other natural image distributions. Zero-shot CLIP models shrink this "robustness gap" by up to 75%. Linear fits on logit transformed values are shown with bootstrap estimated 95% confidence intervals. (Right) Visualizing distribution shift for bananas, a class shared across 5 of the 7 natural distribution shift datasets. The performance of the best zero-shot CLIP model, ViT-L/14@336px, is compared with a model that has the same performance on the ImageNet validation set, ResNet-101.

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_figure_13
chunks.content: Figure: While supervised adaptation to ImageNet increases ImageNet accuracy by 9.2%, it slightly reduces average robustness. (Left) Customizing zero-shot CLIP to each dataset improves robustness compared to using a single static zero-shot ImageNet classifier and pooling predictions across similar classes as in [Taori et al.](#page-33-0) [\(2020\)](#page-33-0). CLIP models adapted to ImageNet have similar effective robustness as the best prior ImageNet models. (Right) Details of per dataset changes in accuracy for the two robustness interventions. Adapting to ImageNet increases accuracy on ImageNetV2 noticeably but trades off accuracy on several other distributions. Dataset specific zero-shot classifiers can improve accuracy by a large amount but are limited to only a few datasets that include classes which don't perfectly align with ImageNet categories. Visual Description: The academic figure compares the performance of various models on adapting to two different strategies: adapting to ImageNet and adapting to class shifts. The left plot shows a scatter of data points representing average performance on seven natural distribution shift datasets against the accuracy on class-subsampled ImageNet, with a dashed line indicating the ideal model performance. The data trends suggest that while adapting to ImageNet improves accuracy (notably +9.2% for ImageNetV2), it slightly reduces robustness, particularly affecting several other datasets negatively. The right panel details specific changes in accuracy for each dataset under both adaptation strategies, highlighting significant gains, particularly a +26.9% increase for Youtube-BB when adapting to class shifts.

metadata.caption: While supervised adaptation to ImageNet increases ImageNet accuracy by 9.2%, it slightly reduces average robustness. (Left) Customizing zero-shot CLIP to each dataset improves robustness compared to using a single static zero-shot ImageNet classifier and pooling predictions across similar classes as in [Taori et al.](#page-33-0) [\(2020\)](#page-33-0). CLIP models adapted to ImageNet have similar effective robustness as the best prior ImageNet models. (Right) Details of per dataset changes in accuracy for the two robustness interventions. Adapting to ImageNet increases accuracy on ImageNetV2 noticeably but trades off accuracy on several other distributions. Dataset specific zero-shot classifiers can improve accuracy by a large amount but are limited to only a few datasets that include classes which don't perfectly align with ImageNet categories.

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_figure_14
chunks.content: Figure: Few-shot CLIP also increases effective robustness compared to existing ImageNet models but is less robust than zero-shot CLIP. Minimizing the amount of ImageNet training data used for adaption increases effective robustness at the cost of decreasing relative robustness. 16-shot logistic regression CLIP matches zero-shot CLIP on ImageNet, as previously reported in Figure 7, but is less robust. Visual Description: The figure displays the relationship between the average performance on class subsampled ImageNet (top-1 accuracy %) plotted on the x-axis and the average performance on seven natural distribution shift datasets on the y-axis. Each data point represents different models: Few-Shot CLIP (red), Zero-Shot CLIP (blue), and others, revealing a positive trend as the amount of training data increases. Notably, while Few-Shot CLIP shows increased robustness compared to standard ImageNet models, it still lags behind Zero-Shot CLIP, aligning with the findings that reducing ImageNet training data may enhance overall effectiveness but also decrease relative robustness.

metadata.caption: Few-shot CLIP also increases effective robustness compared to existing ImageNet models but is less robust than zero-shot CLIP. Minimizing the amount of ImageNet training data used for adaption increases effective robustness at the cost of decreasing relative robustness. 16-shot logistic regression CLIP matches zero-shot CLIP on ImageNet, as previously reported in Figure 7, but is less robust.

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_figure_15
chunks.content: Figure: The hardest problems for CLIP also tend to be the hardest problems for humans. Here we rank image categories by difficulty for CLIP as measured as probability of the correct label. Visual Description: The figure presents a comparison of classification accuracy for various image categories, plotting accuracy percentages on the y-axis against several dog breeds on the x-axis. The data reveals that the Zero-Shot CLIP model (blue line) achieves higher accuracy levels across most categories compared to both One-Shot Humans (orange line) and Zero-Shot Humans (green line), though all models show a general decreasing trend in accuracy with more challenging categories. Key findings indicate that both CLIP and humans encounter similar struggles with harder classifications, highlighting the inherent difficulties in recognizing specific dog breeds.

metadata.caption: The hardest problems for CLIP also tend to be the hardest problems for humans. Here we rank image categories by difficulty for CLIP as measured as probability of the correct label.

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_figure_16
chunks.content: Figure: Few statistically significant improvements in accuracy due to detected data overlap. (Left) While several datasets have up to $\pm 20\%$ apparent differences in zero-shot accuracy on detected overlapping vs clean examples only 5 datasets out of 35 total have 99.5% Clopper-Pearson confidence intervals that exclude a 0% accuracy difference. 2 of these datasets *do worse* on overlapping data. (Right) Since the percentage of detected overlapping examples is almost always in the single digits, the *overall* test accuracy gain due to overlap is much smaller with the largest estimated increase being only 0.6% on Birdsnap. Similarly, for only 6 datasets are the accuracy improvements statistically significant when calculated using a one-sided binomial test.

metadata.caption: Few statistically significant improvements in accuracy due to detected data overlap. (Left) While several datasets have up to  $\pm 20\%$  apparent differences in zero-shot accuracy on detected overlapping vs clean examples only 5 datasets out of 35 total have 99.5% Clopper-Pearson confidence intervals that exclude a 0% accuracy difference. 2 of these datasets *do worse* on overlapping data. (Right) Since the percentage of detected overlapping examples is almost always in the single digits, the *overall* test accuracy gain due to overlap is much smaller with the largest estimated increase being only 0.6% on Birdsnap. Similarly, for only 6 datasets are the accuracy improvements statistically significant when calculated using a one-sided binomial test.

chunks.content: Figure: CLIP performance on Member of Congress images when given the combined returned label set for the images from Google Cloud Vision, Amazon Rekognition and Microsoft Azure Computer Vision. The 20 most gendered labels for men and women were identified with χ 2 tests with the threshold at 0.5%. Labels are sorted by absolute frequencies. Bars denote the percentage of images for a certain label by gender.

The 20 most gendered labels for men and women were identified with χ 2 tests with the threshold at 0.5%. Labels are sorted by absolute frequencies. Bars denote the percentage of images for a certain label by gender.

chunks.content: Figure: Visualization of predictions from 36 CLIP zero-shot classifiers. All examples are random with the exception of reselecting Hateful Memes to avoid offensive content. The predicted probability of the top 5 classes is shown along with the text used to represent the class. When more than one template is used, the first template is shown. The ground truth label is colored green while an incorrect prediction is colored orange. Visual Description: The academic figure presents a grid of predictions from 36 CLIP zero-shot classifiers, where each image corresponds to its predicted classes. Axes labels indicate the predicted class probabilities, with correct predictions highlighted in green and incorrect ones in orange. Key findings reveal varying prediction accuracies across different images, highlighting the model's strengths and weaknesses, such as consistently high accuracy in some classes while struggling with others, which suggests areas for potential improvement in classifier training.

metadata.caption: Visualization of predictions from 36 CLIP zero-shot classifiers. All examples are random with the exception of reselecting Hateful Memes to avoid offensive content. The predicted probability of the top 5 classes is shown along with the text used to represent the class. When more than one template is used, the first template is shown. The ground truth label is colored green while an incorrect prediction is colored orange.

chunks.id: Learning Transferable Visual Models From Natural Language Supervision.pdf_figure_20
chunks.content:
Figure: CLIP's zero-shot performance compared to linear-probe ResNet performance

Visual Description: The figure presents a comparison of CLIP's zero-shot performance (depicted with red stars) against linear-probe ResNet performance (shown with yellow triangles) across various datasets, with accuracy on the y-axis and GFLOPs per image on the x-axis. Key findings indicate that CLIP consistently outperforms ResNet in terms of accuracy across most datasets, particularly as the computational cost (GFLOPs) increases. Notable trends reveal that while ResNet demonstrates gradual performance improvements, CLIP shows a more significant increase in accuracy, especially on complex datasets like ImageNet and MNIST.

metadata.caption: CLIP's zero-shot performance compared to linear-probe ResNet performance

figures.caption: Summary of our approach. While standard image models jointly train an image feature extractor and a linear classifier to predict some label, CLIP jointly trains an image encoder and a text encoder to predict the correct pairings of a batch of (image, text) training examples. At test time the learned text encoder synthesizes a zero-shot linear classifier by embedding the names or descriptions of the target dataset's classes.

CLIP is much more efficient at zero-shot transfer than our image caption baseline. Although highly expressive, we found that transformer-based language models are relatively weak at zero-shot ImageNet classification. Here, we see that it learns 3x slower than a baseline which predicts a bag-of-words (BoW) encoding of the text (Joulin et al., 2016). Swapping the prediction objective for the contrastive objective of CLIP further improves efficiency another 4x.

Prompt engineering and ensembling improve zeroshot performance. Compared to the baseline of using contextless class names, prompt engineering and ensembling boost zero-shot classification performance by almost 5 points on average across 36 datasets. This improvement is similar to the gain from using 4 times more compute with the baseline zero-shot method but is "free" when amortized over many predictions.

Zero-shot CLIP is competitive with a fully supervised baseline. Across a 27 dataset eval suite, a zero-shot CLIP classifier outperforms a fully supervised linear classifier fitted on ResNet-50 features on 16 datasets, including ImageNet.

Zero-shot CLIP outperforms few-shot linear probes. Zero-shot CLIP matches the average performance of a 4-shot linear classifier trained on the same feature space and nearly matches the best results of a 16-shot linear classifier across publicly available models. For both BiT-M and SimCLRv2, the best performing model is highlighted. Light gray lines are other models in the eval suite. The 20 datasets with at least 16 examples per class were used in this analysis.

The data efficiency of zero-shot transfer varies widely. Calculating the number of labeled examples per class a linear classifier on the same CLIP feature space requires to match the performance of the zero-shot classifier contextualizes the effectiveness of zero-shot transfer. Values are estimated based on log-linear interpolation of 1, 2, 4, 8, 16-shot and fully supervised results. Performance varies widely from still underperforming a one-shot classifier on two datasets to matching an estimated 184 labeled examples per class.

Zero-shot performance is correlated with linear probe performance but still mostly sub-optimal. Comparing zero-shot and linear probe performance across datasets shows a strong correlation with zero-shot performance mostly shifted 10 to 25 points lower. On only 5 datasets does zero-shot performance approach linear probe performance ( $\leq$ 3 point difference).

Zero-shot CLIP performance scales smoothly as a function of model compute. Across 39 evals on 36 different datasets, average zero-shot error is well modeled by a log-log linear trend across a 44x range of compute spanning 5 different CLIP models. Lightly shaded lines are performance on individual evals, showing that performance is much more varied despite the smooth overall trend.

Linear probe performance of CLIP models in comparison with state-of-the-art computer vision models, including EfficientNet (Tan & Le, 2019; Xie et al., 2020), MoCo (Chen et al., 2020d), Instagram-pretrained ResNeXt models (Mahajan et al., 2018; Touvron et al., 2019), BiT (Kolesnikov et al., 2019), ViT (Dosovitskiy et al., 2020), SimCLRv2 (Chen et al., 2020c), BYOL (Grill et al., 2020), and the original ResNet models (He et al., 2016b). (Left) Scores are averaged over 12 datasets studied by Kornblith et al. (2019). (Right) Scores are averaged over 27 datasets that contain a wider variety of distributions. Dotted lines indicate models fine-tuned or evaluated on images at a higher-resolution than pre-training. See Table 10 for individual scores and Figure 20 for plots for each dataset.

CLIP's features outperform the features of the best ImageNet model on a wide variety of datasets. Fitting a linear classifier on CLIP's features outperforms using the Noisy Student EfficientNet-L2 on 21 out of 27 datasets.

CLIP's features are more robust to task shift when compared to models pre-trained on ImageNet. For both dataset splits, the transfer scores of linear probes trained on the representations of CLIP models are higher than other models with similar ImageNet performance. This suggests that the representations of models trained on ImageNet are somewhat overfit to their task.

Zero-shot CLIP is much more robust to distribution shift than standard ImageNet models. (Left) An ideal robust model (dashed line) performs equally well on the ImageNet distribution and on other natural image distributions. Zero-shot CLIP models shrink this "robustness gap" by up to 75%. Linear fits on logit transformed values are shown with bootstrap estimated 95% confidence intervals. (Right) Visualizing distribution shift for bananas, a class shared across 5 of the 7 natural distribution shift datasets. The performance of the best zero-shot CLIP model, ViT-L/14@336px, is compared with a model that has the same performance on the ImageNet validation set, ResNet-101.

While supervised adaptation to ImageNet increases ImageNet accuracy by 9.2%, it slightly reduces average robustness. (Left) Customizing zero-shot CLIP to each dataset improves robustness compared to using a single static zero-shot ImageNet classifier and pooling predictions across similar classes as in [Taori et al.](#page-33-0) [\(2020\)](#page-33-0). CLIP models adapted to ImageNet have similar effective robustness as the best prior ImageNet models. (Right) Details of per dataset changes in accuracy for the two robustness interventions. Adapting to ImageNet increases accuracy on ImageNetV2 noticeably but trades off accuracy on several other distributions. Dataset specific zero-shot classifiers can improve accuracy by a large amount but are limited to only a few datasets that include classes which don't perfectly align with ImageNet categories.

Few-shot CLIP also increases effective robustness compared to existing ImageNet models but is less robust than zero-shot CLIP. Minimizing the amount of ImageNet training data used for adaption increases effective robustness at the cost of decreasing relative robustness. 16-shot logistic regression CLIP matches zero-shot CLIP on ImageNet, as previously reported in Figure 7, but is less robust.
The hardest problems for CLIP also tend to be the hardest problems for humans. Here we rank image categories by difficulty for CLIP as measured as probability of the correct label.

Few statistically significant improvements in accuracy due to detected data overlap. (Left) While several datasets have up to  $\pm 20\%$  apparent differences in zero-shot accuracy on detected overlapping vs clean examples only 5 datasets out of 35 total have 99.5% Clopper-Pearson confidence intervals that exclude a 0% accuracy difference. 2 of these datasets *do worse* on overlapping data. (Right) Since the percentage of detected overlapping examples is almost always in the single digits, the *overall* test accuracy gain due to overlap is much smaller with the largest estimated increase being only 0.6% on Birdsnap. Similarly, for only 6 datasets are the accuracy improvements statistically significant when calculated using a one-sided binomial test.

CLIP performance on Member of Congress images when given the combined returned label set for the images from Google Cloud Vision, Amazon Rekognition and Microsoft Azure Computer Vision. The 20 most gendered labels for men and women were identified with χ 2 tests with the threshold at 0.5%. Labels are sorted by absolute frequencies. Bars denote the percentage of images for a certain label by gender.
